summary.title: Product Summary
summary.description: Stadli is the all-in-one revenue + marketing OS for pro teams outside the big four. It launches with five integrated cores that work together from day one.

cores.name: Web App / Website
cores.description: A PWA-first team hub combining a modern web experience and branded app shell. Includes Game Day Central, sponsor surfaces, push notifications, and built-in checkout for tickets, merch, and experiences.

cores.name: CRM / 360° Fan Profile
cores.description: Unified fan database stitching ticketing, merch, and digital touchpoints into a single view. Enables live segmentation, lifecycle tracking, and identity resolution for every fan.

cores.name: Campaign Engine & Playbooks
cores.description: Multi-channel campaign system with sports-ready templates and prebuilt revenue plays. Launch push/email automations, drive purchases, and measure closed-loop revenue attribution from message to checkout.

cores.name: Stadli Narratives & Analytics
cores.description: Daily role-based digest (email + dashboard) with one-click, prefilled actions tailored to GM, Marketing, and Ops roles. Powered by Stadli Web Tag for standardized analytics, event tracking, and attribution.

cores.name: Commerce & Ticketing
cores.description: Native ticketing and ecommerce layer with secure payment processing, unified checkout, fan wallet, and real-time reconciliation with Tixr and Shopify webhooks.

development_philosophy.title: Development Philosophy & Best Practices
development_philosophy.summary: Our approach to building Stadli is grounded in a set of core principles that ensure stability, scalability, and maintainability.

principles.name: Safe Experimentation
principles.description: New work is isolated to prevent production risk.
practices: Sandboxes & Playgrounds: Every new feature, integration, or significant change is first developed and tested in isolated sandbox environments.
This allows for free experimentation without any risk to production data or services.

principles.name: Production Integrity
principles.description: Production is protected by process and automation.
practices: Protecting Production: The production environment is sacred. Direct changes are strictly forbidden.
All deployments follow a rigorous CI/CD pipeline with automated checks, and rollbacks are planned for.

principles.name: Documentation as a Deliverable
principles.description: Documentation is part of the product, produced continuously.
practices: Continuous Documentation: Every API endpoint, data model change, and architectural decision is documented as it's made.

principles.name: Visibility and Auditing
practices: Comprehensive Logging: Structured logs for application events, errors, and access patterns are maintained to debug issues, monitor performance, and audit activity effectively.

principles.name: Built for Change
principles.description: Architecture favors modularity and loose coupling.
practices: Modular Architecture: Components are loosely coupled and communicate through well-defined APIs.
This enables updating, replacing, or scaling individual parts without affecting the entire platform.

principles.name: LLM-Centric Architecture
principles.description: Living documentation for AI collaboration and developer onboarding.
practices: Every directory and module contains a dedicated context file (e.g., "_context.md").
This file serves as a "living document" explaining the purpose, key functions, and relationships of the code within it.
Ensures any developer or Large Language Model (LLM) can instantly grasp context for AI-assisted development, refactoring, and debugging.

usage.primaryAccentSelectionRule: Pick exactly one accent family per artifact; dashboards may use accents with clear separation.

usage.chartAccentPolicy: Exactly one accent per chart; all other series use neutrals (baselineColor/textSecondary). Do not accent axes, gridlines, or legends.

rotationPolicy.rule: Always vary feature and use colors across designs depending on context.
constraints: Do not repeat the same accent family in consecutive assets within the same campaign unless semantically required (e.g., Revenue → electricOrange).
When two feature cards appear on the same surface, use different families from their primary/alternate sets.
rotationPolicy.fallback: If conflict remains, prefer alternates in order listed under featureColorAssignments.

steps: Start with intent and audience: define the job of the piece (Sell, Prove, Educate, Announce) and the one feeling/action you want to drive.
Choose a narrative frame that fits the context (promise-first, proof-first, or story-then-offer). Keep headlines tight and declarative.
Select a single accent family that semantically reinforces the message (e.g., Revenue → electricOrange). Use it to guide attention, not decorate.
Establish hierarchy that survives any medium: outcome line → supporting line → single next step. The message should read clearly with or without imagery.
Pair words with the clearest evidence for the channel: photo for human moments, chart for change, mock for product clarity—graspable at a glance.
Add 1–3 supporting modules that ladder back to the promise (features, metrics, case proof, testimonial/logo strip). Order flexes to suit the context.
Fit the structure to the medium: layout grid/typographic rhythm for print/web; visual sequence/beat for video; spatial balance for OOH; scannable blocks for email/social.
Close decisively with one action and a confidence cue (short testimonial, logo strip, guarantee, or data source).
Throughout: keep neutrals dominant, maintain strong contrast and legibility, vary accents across a campaign set, and avoid visual noise.
Favor photographic or motion-based evidence (fan faces, stadium scenes, player action) as primary proof elements when emotion or community is central.
compositionAlgorithm.accentSelectionRule: Choose exactly one accent family per artifact; complex, data-dense pieces may use two in clearly separated zones. Apply accents only where emphasis is needed (chips, icons, charts, highlights, focus states). Action elements remain neutral.
